text:
Apache becomes permanently unresponsive if /var fills up.  But, it was decided 
that having a frozen web server is better than exiting cleanly with an error 
message, so bug 17898 was marked as wontfix.  Therefore this bug is an 
enhancement?

There needs to be a way to poll Apache and determine authoritatively whether or 
not it is in this frozen state.  This will then allow users to do automated 
logging, restarts, or other notification, as they see fit.  Currently if you 
are trying to achieve high levels of uptime, Apache is a liability.

>There needs to be a way to poll Apache and determine authoritatively whether or 
>not it is in this frozen state.

Typical polling mechanism used by content switches is to try to issue a simple
request, such as "HEAD /", and if timeout occurs at any stage (connect, send
request, receive response) then the web server is dead and needs intervention. 
(IIRC the timeout has to occur several times in succession to be considered a
failure.)
I
t would be interesting to see which operation is hanging when /var fills up.  If
you recreate the hang again, try getting backtraces with gdb to see what Apache
is trying to do.
